I believe that many, if not most, of our problems can be traced to the failure of the Founding Fathers to write term limits into the Constitution. They assumed that public minded people would be 'citizen-statesmen' and go back to a real life after serving no more than two terms in office, e.g. George Washington who declined entreaties to serve a third term as President.

So now, we have Harry Reid, Barbara Boxer, Maxine Waters, and Diane Feinstein in office forever, and that is just to cite some of the Left Coast crowd. Jane Harman is gone only because she was recorded committing treason by the NSA which led to her mid-term resignation from Congress.

Term limits for Congress will never happen because they themselves would have to vote to derail their endless gravy train. Not too likely methinks.

Ditto. I would have liked to have had children but chose not to because of my history with chronic severe depression, dysthymia, and anxiety. It was not simply the possibly of passing on the genetic predisposition for it, but the double-whammy of the nature-and-nurture problem. On the one hand, severely depressed people usually don't make very good parents, so kids are affected regardless of whether they inherit the genetic predisposition for it.  On the other hand, some people who have suffered from depression and emerged from the worst of it can have insight, compassion, and wisdom that can make them strong parents, but their insight tells them that they may pass on a genetic predisposition for this horrible disorder.  The risk that a depressed parent will produce a depressed child seems to far outweigh the risk that a parent being treated for depression will produce a child with autism.

I didn't have kids because my father beat me when I was one and I figured that when I saw how sweet my kids would be, I'd want to go kick my father's a$$, and that wouldn't be legal.  So since I have been on every AD known to Madison avenue, I think that since none of them work to make the endless question-less din of metropolitan life non-annoying, I'm pretty sure all my values are merely screwy.  I need to go get the ducks off the pond.  It's very relaxing.

Kudos. I wish every person who has a serious condition, whether physical or mental, would think like Michael  and refrain from putting more suffering children in this world. Life is tough enough without having to be brought up by a chronically  ill or depressed parent. I wish more people would  stop thinking that having children is the end-all and be-all of everything.

My entire family--grandparents, parents, siblings, myself--suffers from mood and anxiety disorders.  I would not wish my struggles with depression on my worst enemy, and I was concerned about passing these bad genes on to any offspring.  Hence, for me (a male) it was not a question of the effects of gestating a baby while depressed or while taking anti-depressants, but a question of the likelihood of passing this disease on to future generations.  I decided that it had to stop with me, and I do not have biological children.  Call it self-aware natural selection.

In Sanskrit, all words ending in a consonant have a half "a" sound, sort of like the "a" in "atone." So, "Rama (pronounced Rämɘ) is the correct Romanization of the Sanskrit word, and the same applies to Hanumana," and "Yoga." The mistake people make is that they pronounce the "a" at the end as the "a" in "father" (i.e. Rämä).

However, Ram, Hanuman, and Yog are incorrect. They are romanizations of Hindi vulgarizations of the Sanskrit words.

The problems are not of overconfidence but the outcomes of hubris and the self-centered goals of sociopaths.

In particular I'd like to comment and expand on your third comment. As a graduate student from another country, I was taken aback in my first few classes when American students with little knowledge spoke with great confidence, an act that would have been met with either a gentle rebuke or derision in most other countries. I surmised that American spoke with self confidence and self assurance even if they were misplaced or unwarranted. Now, almost four decades later, I still see Americans dominate the conversation even if their knowledge does not justify their stage time.
I think it is important to balance self-criticism with self-confidence. As they say of Prince Philip, it is often better to be thought of as a fool than to open one's mouth and provide evidence.

Excellent column with probing questions. My answers:

1) Women are schooled to be as confident as men, but workplace experience may well erode this self-confidence, especially in male-dominated fields.
2) To date, sadly, women have been more likely to have been promoted in supporting fields, including human resources and administration. In male-dominated fields, the same is true. In commercial real estate, for example, women are more likely to be promoted in a supporting field (property management) than in a dominant field (leasing or investment sales brokerage.)
3)In the U.S., the ability to self-criticize is not only undervalued, it is denigrated.
4)At high levels of achievement in U.S. organizations, problems are generally the product of overconfidence. Some examples: Vietnam, Watergate, Enron, the financial meltdown. If you think you're the smartest one in the room, be assured: you're not.
Who was more self-confident than George W Bush, invading Iraq and proclaiming "Mission Accomplished" in a flight suit a full seven years before we withdrew. Self-confidence is *vastly* overrated.
Behind American bluster there is nothing at all.

Self-confidence has a way of morphing into smugness and, at times, shallowness. I, for one, don't want to be surrounded by hordes of used car salesmen, their eyes boring into mine and then maiming me with bone-crushing handshakes. It is an overrated pose.

There has been a huge investment in popularizing the austerity policy position, the virtues of free enterprise and keeping Government under control. This investment has built an illusion around "Fix the Deficit" that a lot of the very serious economics/financial establishment have been hooked. They are confused. It is extremely difficult to think through the economy in a clear headed, historical evidence basis. This year, I was stunned by the position taken by Paul Volcker, one of my heroes, in support of Pete Peterson et al's position of the deficit crisis. It is difficult to not get caught up in the delusion that if we just rein in government all will be well and the private wealth of the United States will then begin to generate wealth & very competitive products and services with lots to go around for all. I think this explains what happened to Robert Samuelson. If is difficult to maintain contact with reality & the misery that we are creating with long-term unemployment. I am lucky because I am exposed to two 50 plus years sons, 3 adult post college age grandchildren and many very intelligent scientist friends who think that we must turn our attention to the long-term issues like efficient non-fossil fuel transportation & industrial processes to reduce greenhouse gas emissions & use this noble industrial goal to create jobs & a prosperous future for all humanity. We are confident in the survivability of homo sapiens (the wise ones), if we work at it..

Point taken, I was thinking more of feral (not house-bound) cats. I've had cats and enjoy them, but it comes with a price. For shear damage to the ecosystem, whatever that may mean anymore, they're hard to top.

To EC:

One could argue that hunting, by definition, is more humane than factory farming. Pigs and other livestock live horrible, torturous, filthy, cramped lives on factory farms. The wild boars, on the other hand, live a free-ranging, foraging, natural life ... up to the point when they meet their maker (or, rather, their prosciutto-maker.) If you have to eat meat, I'd put hunting on the top of the humane ways to get it, followed by free-range organic farming. Factory farming is not even on the list.
The case that Bruni makes for reducing feral pig numbers applies equally well to house cats, excepting the flavor I would imagine.
